name: CalcificationDistributionCS
title: Calcification Distribution CodeSystem
description: Calcification Distribution in an abnormality code system.

concept.definition:
[PR] Clustered distribution
Clustered Distribution is in regards to a type of calcification with at least 5 calcifications occupying a small volume of tissue.
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Diffuse distribution
C1268689
[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
Diffuse (historically, "scattered"). These are calcifications that are distributed randomly throughout the breast. Punctate and amorphous calcifications in this distribution are almost always benign, especially if bilateral.
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Grouped distribution
C1268691
[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
This term should be used when relatively few calcifications occupy a small portion of breast tissue. The lower limit for use of this descriptor is usually when 5 calcifications are grouped within 1 cm of each other or when a definable pattern is identified. The upper limit for use of this descriptor is when larger numbers of calcifications are grouped within 2 cm of each other.)
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Linear distribution
C1268690
[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
These are calcifications arrayed in a line. This distribution may elevate suspicion for malignancy, as it suggests deposits in a duct. Note that both vascular and large rod-like calcifications also are usually linear in distribution, but that these typically benign calcifications have a characteristically benign morphology.)
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Regional distribution
C1268692
[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
This descriptor is used for numerous calcifications that occupy a large portion of breast tissue (more than 2 cm in greatest dimension), not conforming to a duct distribution. Since this distribution may involve most of a quadrant or even more than a single quadrant, malignancy is less likely. However, overall evaluation of regional calcifications must include particle shape (morphology) as well as distribution.
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Scattered distribution
Refers to a type of calcification of the breast. Scattered calcifications or multiple similar appearing clusters of calcifications throughout the whole breast.

Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Segmental distribution
C1268693
[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
Calcifications in a segmental distribution are of concern because they suggest deposits in a duct or ducts and their branches, raising the possibility of extensive or multifocal breast cancer in a lobe or segment of the breast. Although benign causes of segmental calcifications exist (e.g. large rod-like), the smooth, rod-like morphology and large size of benign calcifications distinguish them from finer, more pleomorphic or heterogeneous malignant calcifications. A segmental distribution may elevate the degree of suspicion for calcifications such as punctate or amorphous forms.
Valid for the following modalities: MG.
